title: Chapter 13 – Functions, Parameters, and Return Values Checkpoint
description: Quick concept-check for chapter 13. Test your understanding of function definitions, parameters, default values, and return.

questions.prompt: What is a function in Python?

options.label: A way to repeat code by giving it a name and calling it.

explanations.overview: Functions are named blocks of code you can reuse by calling them.

byOptionId.a: Correct – functions let you group code and call it by name.
byOptionId.b: Lists store data; functions are actions.
byOptionId.d: Comments start with # and are not functions.

questions.prompt: Which keyword is used to define a function in Python?

explanations.overview: Function definitions always start with def.

byOptionId.a: func is not a Python keyword.
byOptionId.b: Correct – def starts a function definition.
byOptionId.c: function is not a keyword in Python.
byOptionId.d: call is not a keyword either.

options.label: A parameter (an input to the function).

explanations.overview: Parameters are variables listed in the function definition header.

byOptionId.a: Return values come from the return statement, not from the header.
byOptionId.b: Correct – name is the parameter the function expects.
byOptionId.c: There is nothing wrong with this code.
byOptionId.d: List items live inside lists, not in function headers.

questions.prompt: What does the return statement do in a function?

options.label: It prints text to the screen.
It stops the function and sends a value back.

explanations.overview: return exits the function and hands a value back to the caller.

byOptionId.a: print shows a value, but does not return it.
byOptionId.b: Correct – this is exactly what return does.
byOptionId.c: Loops use for or while, not return.

questions.prompt: In `def greet(name, greeting='Hi')`, what happens if you call `greet('Alex')`?

explanations.overview: Default parameter values are used when you don't pass that argument.

byOptionId.b: Correct - 'Hi' is used as the default greeting.
byOptionId.c: None is not used here; we gave a real default string.
byOptionId.d: Python does not ignore parameters; it fills them with defaults if needed.
